Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of Syrian refugees that President Obama wants to take in by stating it as 250,000, while there is no evidence to support this number.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support or evidence to back up the statement that President Obama wants to take in 250,000 Syrian refugees.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that President Obama wants to take in a specific number of Syrian refugees without providing sufficient evidence or sources to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that the claim is based on misinformation or incorrect reports about the citizenship status of the Paris attackers, which led to the assumption that President Obama wants to allow hundreds of thousands of Syrians entry to the United States.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Syrian passport found next to the body of one of the Paris attackers was believed to be fake, and most of the attackers were European nationals, not Syrian refugees.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by relying on statements made by Donald Trump and other Republican presidential candidates, which may not always be accurate or reliable.
Understate: The claim may understate the actual number of Syrian refugees that President Obama has decided to admit, as there are plans to admit more refugees, including Syrians, over several years according to PolitiFact.
